results.title: Fist II - The Legend Continues for ZX Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and paper insert in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Fist II - The Legend Continues [computer game]. Fist II is a single player side scrolling beat ‘em up with adventure elements. Players travel through different environments, fighting various enemies, collecting items and visiting temples to power up the character to be strong enough to defeat the warlord and free the land.
results.title_for_label: Fist II - The Legend Continues for ZX Spectrum 48/128
results.description: Fist II - The Legend Continues [computer game]. Fist II is a single player side scrolling beat ‘em up with adventure elements. Players travel through different environments, fighting various enemies, collecting items and visiting temples to power up the character to be strong enough to defeat the warlord and free the land.
description_for_label: Fist II - The Legend Continues [computer game]. Fist II is a single player side scrolling beat ‘em up with adventure elements. Players travel through different environments, fighting various enemies, collecting items and visiting temples to power up the character to be strong enough to defeat the warlord and free the land.

results.title: Doc the Destroyer for Commodore 64/128
results.creator_credit: Geoff Evans, Paul Kidd, Melbourne House and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and manual booklet in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Doc the Destroyer [computer game]. Doc the Destroyer is a side view, strategy arcade adventure in a post apocalyptic setting for one player. At the start of the game, players are given 60 points which they can distribute between five statistics Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck and Charisma. As Doc, players are presented with various choices that determine your next action and some will throw the player into arcade styled combat.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoff Evans, Paul Kidd, Melbourne House and Beam Software
results.description: Doc the Destroyer [computer game]. Doc the Destroyer is a side view, strategy arcade adventure in a post apocalyptic setting for one player. At the start of the game, players are given 60 points which they can distribute between five statistics Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck and Charisma. As Doc, players are presented with various choices that determine your next action and some will throw the player into arcade styled combat.
description_for_label: Doc the Destroyer [computer game]. Doc the Destroyer is a side view, strategy arcade adventure in a post apocalyptic setting for one player. At the start of the game, players are given 60 points which they can distribute between five statistics Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck and Charisma. As Doc, players are presented with various choices that determine your next action and some will throw the player into arcade styled combat.

results.title: The Tolkien Trilogy  for Commodore 64
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Two cassettes, paper manual, plastic cassette tray in a cardboard case
results.brief_description: Contains three games: ‘The Hobbit’, ‘Lord of the Rings’ and ‘Shadows of Mordor’. The games are loosely based on “The Hobbit” and “The Lord of the Rings” novels by J.R.R Tolkien
results.description: Contains three games: ‘The Hobbit’, ‘Lord of the Rings’ and ‘Shadows of Mordor’. The games are loosely based on “The Hobbit” and “The Lord of the Rings” novels by J.R.R Tolkien

results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Bedlam [computer game]. Bedlam is a top down vertical shooting scroller in a futuristic sci fi setting for one or two players simultaneously. Players pilot a vehicle shooting and dodging aliens and fighting boss ships.

results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Bedlam [computer game]. Bedlam is a top down vertical shooting scroller in a futuristic sci fi setting for one or two players simultaneously. Players pilot a vehicle shooting and dodging aliens and fighting boss ships.

results.title: Demon Stalkers for Commodore 64/128
results.creator_credit: Electronic Arts and Micro Forte Studios
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, code wheel, warranty card & manual (paper booklet) in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Demon Stalkers is an action RPG and editor/construction set game. It is similar to Atari’s Gauntlet. The player can choose either the hero, armed with throwing knives, or the heroine, armed with a crossbow who must travel through ninety-nine mazes before meeting the final demon. The game features different enemies as you progress through the mazes, with clues to progression built in. There is also a two-player co-operative mode. The in-built level editor uses pull-down menus and offers a high level of flexibility. As well as creating actual levels, the player can create an integrated storyline and game world, since the in-game text can also be edited.
The game shipped with a Magic Cipher consisting of three cardboard wheels that, when moved to the correct positions, revealed the passwords were needed to access some of the lower levels of the dungeon. Some of the vital text in the cipher is in a tone of blue that could not be photocopied at that point, making the cipher a basic anti-piracy measure.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/demon-stalkers/

Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Micro Forte Studios for Commodore 64 and 128, published in 1987 by Electronic Arts.

results.title: Rangi and papa: the Maori creation myth
results.brief_description: The Maori myth about the creation of the Earth. Life began with the Sky Father and the Earth Mother, who gave birth to the gods of the sea, winds and storms, food, forests, plunder, and earthquakes. Animated film with script and illustrations by Robert Jahnke, photography by Lindsay Whipp and narrated by George Henare.

results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Black Hole Radio
results.material_description: Single-channel video, b&w and colour, audio
results.brief_description:
Over the past 20 years, filmmaker Jem Cohen has assembled a massive visual archive of Super 8 and 16mm by filming everyday images and experiences as he negotiates his way through the spaces of New York City. Filled with enigmatic glimpses, gestures and images seeming to come from half-remembered dreams, memories and snatches of conversations, this archive contains hints for unearthing the many secrets of contemporary metropolitan life.
In the mid 1990s Cohen encountered a series of advertisements for a New York City ‘Phone Confession Line’.To call in and confess was free; to listen cost money. Cohen acquired recordings of these taped confessions of murderous thoughts, desire and treachery, and used them to form the audio heartbeat of his video installation ‘Black Hole Radio’. Accompanied by ghostly Super 8 images filmed by the artist during his nocturnal wanderings, the installation reveals the anonymous lives and restless spirits that haunt the phonelines, televisions and sleepless nights of the city.
For this version of the installation, ACMI has worked with the artist to create a small confessional cell where images shimmer like paranoid hallucinations while disturbing whispers hang in mid-air, semi-publicly. The elusive images that linger on the edge of visual perception provide the evidence of Cohen’s investigation into the small confessed ‘crimes’: loving the wrong man, harbouring hatred or greed. Visitors leave ‘Black Hole Radio’ feeling the way they do when a shameful memory wakes them in the dead of night. Inside Cohen’s confessional, it is understood that it is both a privilege and a curse: to live as social beings and to know that isolation and forgetting can’t conceal the troubled heart of the city.

results.title: Pathways
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, projections, text, audio, bespoke screens, tiered  wooden seating , timber and LED strips
results.brief_description:
A collaboration between artist-filmmaker Jeff Doring and the Ngarinyin Aboriginal Corporation. This spatial installation provides access and insight into the art and culture of the Ngarinyin people. The intention is to record and interpret a broad spectrum of Ngarinyin knowledge and law. The work consists of five discrete and interrelated elements:
1. The Introduction zone: a space consisting of a text, audio, visual introduction to the installation.
2. The Water and Wanjina zone: a corridor with apertures that open on the side to reveal visual works.
3. The Man Blood Law zone: a three screen installation with tiered seating that lies at the end of the Water and Wanjina corridor.
4. The Cave zone: an exhibition space which spatially represents a cave with images projected inside it.
5. The Today zone: a space which provides a contemporary perspective on the exhibition via a web installation.

details.label: Materials
display_values: Multi-channel installation, video, projections, text, audio, bespoke screens, tiered  wooden seating , timber and LED strips
